Message.Title: LBO not stock deal
Message.Msg: Even the talking heads on CNBC appear to be missing the value here. This is an LBO not a stock deal. Private equity does not pay full cash value for a company like dell. If the cash offer is 13.50 they must believe it worth 20% more than that assuming the $13.50 is the top price they are willing to pay. The rush is to get it before another suitor steps in. I like this one .

Topic.Title: why did Dell leak out potential buyout info so soon?

Message.Msg: ... and that dividend payment .... Y declaring a dividend and then considering to go private ? to pump up the price ? really strange ...

M. Dell has a win-win plan, the consortium loads up on dell stock, they try to steal it for $15 a share, go on the "GO SHOP" period for a month, if a higher bid comes out, sell at a nice profit, if not, they get the company on the cheap. As you say, I like this one, not for what it does in the next few days but for what will come in the next few weeks

Topic.Title: why did Dell leak out potential buyout info so soon?

Message.Msg: Two totally different things. The company isn't considering going private - a deal/offer has not even been made to the company/BOD yet.

Yeah - Carly is a real expert when it comes to buying PC companies - like ramming that Compaq buyout through HP to serve herself a nice big bonus at the expense of shareholders. One of the biggest HP failures of all time and Carly's been giving numerous interviews lately, first on Autonomy fiasco and now Dell. This is the way that HP CEOs are groomed - they have to initiate a big acquisition to jack up their compensation. Is it any wonder why Leo bought Autonomy?

Message.Title: $20 share minimum
Message.Msg: I don’t see DELL being taken out for anything less than $20/sh. Dell’s PC business may not be making much... but overall... Dell is becoming a mini-IBM... think of DELL as an enterprise solutions company. Dell’s “normalized” earnings are around $1.70/sh... lower than previous years... still good... how can the stock only go for a p/e in the single digits... prev 10k shows Dell “. . . repurchased approximately 178 million shares of common stock for $2.7 billion during Fiscal 2012 . . .” That’s about 10% of the shs o/s. So why not just keep up the repurchases? Why the rush to sell? In the meantime, Dell pays a very sustainable .32/sh dividend... or about 2.6% of share price... not a bad yield. If they want my shares north of $20... then fine... I can see an HP, Samsung, IBM or another cash-rich tech firm stepping in & acquiring for the economies of scale that would result. The acquisiton would be almost instantly accretive to acquirer’s earnings.

Message.Title: Is there a higher threshold of shareholder approval
Message.Msg: when you have an LBO/Owner takeover of a company? Anyone? Everyone is talking about what the OFFER price might be, but you still have to have shareholder approval. Common sense seems to apply here, most of these funds have a higher average purchase price.
David Faber from CNBC started the BO rumor, helping buddies. Imo

Topic.Title: Is there a higher threshold of shareholder approval

Message.Msg: Wheres an offer, its all smoke n mirror . Organized Pump n Dump crated by CNBC so called Analysts. Imo

Topic.Title: Is there a higher threshold of shareholder approval

Message.Msg: I think the Board w/ have to approve the offer... I don't think it needs to be put to the shareholders. And like others are saying... where's the actual offer?

Sorry Lenny - it's going to happen well below $20. LBO offer will be at something in $13 to $14 range and there will be no competing offers. If the market kicked the shares and trashed the company at $9 and $10, why do you think someone else is going to come along with $20? It's now beyond simply share price. Let's suppose an offer came at $20, it would not succeed unless Michael accepted. I think that at this point he's on a mission - he wants to take it private under his own control. The LBO provides him the means to do it. And, In my mind, the strength of the company is specifically the reason Michael is going about it this way - to show Wall St. that it has no business sticking its nose into the operations or direction of a company. The shares have been undervalued for quite some time. The $13 to $14 offer was probably decided in the days the market trashed the stock down below $9 two months ago - so they can say the offer is at a 50% premium. I assure you, there's no $20 offer waiting in the wings. This story is just about over. And just to quell any flames - I'm not short, just realistic.

Topic.Title: Is there a higher threshold of shareholder approval

Message.Msg: Lucky_lenny First get your facts right. Dell is not Mom n Pops computer fixing shop. Its a public trading company which requires shareholders acceptance regarding any BO. Imo

Message.Title: Dell Hype!
Message.Msg: No Deal! imo... Sooooo Sorry!

No he didn't....the talks are real and confirmed, its no rumour mate...Nip has it right though, we aren't seeing $20 if an LBO happens, lucky if we see $16-17....but even if a LBO does not happen, the stock won't be driven down, b/c its financials are solid and it was way undervalued before the LBO talks...and Faber isn't helping his 'buddies' at £13-14 a share, the 52 week high is over $18...and its nose dived over the last 4 years...$13-14 is only helping people like me, who bought in early november in the high 9s...I didn't stock up massive, but I'm up over $3 on a good chuck of shares already...so no way did Farber start a rumour to help his buddies...the LBO is real, the talks are intense, it might fall through b/c the major holder besides Dell himself, probably won't approve the LBO so low, as they bought from $49 to $25 a share....that is the barrier....look who own the most behind Dell, and look at their positions...that is the barrier...not the money, not Dell, but his second biggest shareholder....either way, no matter what happens, if you bought dell below $10, your going to be just fine NO matter what happens....

slickvguy, you definitely nailed the $12.50 call, can't do any better than that. Is Michael Dell going to be buying more shares in this privatization, or is he selling? If he is actually trying to accumulate shares that suggests a higher price is deserved. If he is reducing his position (puking) then we can't go up too much from $13. Watching the options the last couple days and was surprised to see the August 15 calls trade 8 cents. Somebody is super cnfident that the price is below $5. That was after the CNBC story. Would be really funny if CNBC's sources were using them as a means to get extremely cheap upside leverage and hit a grand slam with a $17 takeout.

Message.Title: not a short by any means
Message.Msg: good luck
I AM UP TODAY!

charlie, 1) MD is not selling. He is most likely getting more skin in the game by adding more of his own money. This is not a Schulze/BBY situation. 2) I don't ever listen to CNBC or analysts or the media. Don't trust them at all. I agree with your theory. I believe that the story was planted to keep a lid on the price and manage expectations. If this thing had just kept rising into the $14's, then it would seem like zero premium by the time the offer is made public. It seems highly likely, given the different leaks, rumours, "no comments", and most importantly MD's own statements, that they are in the process of trying to get a deal done. But will it actually happen? At what price? When would it happen? Except for a handful of people - nobody knows. Certainly not some CNBC stooge. Pay no attention to the noise of the media. Block it out. My guess would be somewhere around $15 - but you never know. This thing is far from over. There will be twists and turns ahead. If you look at the previous 30 or 90 day average DELL stock price (which is how the BOD view it - not where Dell was a year ago, etc), as well as the fundamental values, $15 provides a very justifiable premium. I think this play is a good proposition because I think Dell is in the process of turning itself around even if there is no deal. I'm not concerned with the price so much - it'll be higher than my cost, it's really more a question of a) whether it'll happen at all, and b) WHEN. I'd be extremely surprised if it was as low as $13.50. $15 (or higher) makes much more sense for all involved, but there is a real limit to what makes sense for PE (i.e. dreams of $20 I just can't see happening). At least you can somewhat predict, plus or minus a buck or two, what Dell will fall to if there is no deal. I remember when the Potash deal got killed by Cdn. govt. Sold off for a short while and then went nowhere but up. lol. 3) Yes, the options are surprisingly cheap. That tells you about PERCEPTION - not necessarily reality. The OTM puts are pretty cheap too. I normally sell puts in situations like this but I'm not even bothering. The small premium isn't worth the additional risk. I'm currently just long, no options position (rare for me), and will hold and accumulate more shares on any weakness.

Actually, you are nuts if you think that my intention was to lower the price. lolololol. As if anything written on these boards impacts the price? Get serious. I was not bashing Dell. I was stating my observations. I am never a cheerleader or a basher. I try to look at things as objectively as I can. I believe a deal will happen, that there are significant risks (i.e. it won't be smooth sailing), and that the price will be around $15. I do not believe there will be any other offers made.

Message.Title: Disastrous shopping cart
Message.Msg: If you get pulled away from your computer, your shopping cart expires and you lose everything. You can save your cart, but then you cant get back to it. Luckily, I had a cached page and moved the items to "My Saved Items". I figured since the cart doesnt save anything for more than 30 minutes, the place called SAVED ITEMS would SAVE THEM. And maybe it does, but I cant view "My Saved Items" unless I have 1 item in "wish List". There is no wish list. This is the only place I see any mention of "wish list" on the entire site. If I put something into my shopping cart on Amazon, I can come back in 2 years and its STILL THERE. My new HP desktop should be here in a few days.

Message.Title: Amazing to me
Message.Msg: I can't possibly fathom that investors and especially investors at this level would even consider bailing out Michael Dell at this point. This company is in shambles and the reason Michael is wanting to do this is so they can cover up the failure of their investments over the last 5 years. Every division of Dell is broken or nearly broken and their M&A strategy has been a complete bust for the business. Dell is a sales and operation machine, they are not an IP company and they will never change that and for that matter, why would they really want to change that? Their success is a derivative of their channel to the market, not IP. This whole thing is M. Dell Ego based and investors should be very concerned short of selling off the under performing nonsense that they spent Billions on and turning the company back to what they are good at. Moving Products.
I was hearing that the deal could go down as early as next week. I bet we go higher tomorrow due to the fact that most people don't want to be left out if the deal were to happen over the weekend.
